title: Holy Water
summary: Blessed water recalling Baptism; used for protection, purification, and blessings.
history: Documented use by the early Church (4th–5th c.); linked to baptismal liturgies; aspersion rites widespread by the Middle Ages.
theology: Sacramental sign; not a sacrament; by the Church’s prayer it disposes to grace and protection against evil; recalls baptismal dignity.
usage: Blessing oneself on entering a church
notes: Often contains blessed salt in some rites; local customs vary.

title: Crucifix
summary: A cross bearing the corpus of Christ; focus of Christian meditation on the Passion.
history: Use of the cross dates to the apostolic age; crucifixes prominent by 6th–7th c.; Council of Trent affirmed veneration of sacred images (1545–1563).
theology: Points to the one sacrifice of Christ; images receive relative honor (dulia); worship is to God alone.
notes: Eastern Christians often use an icon cross; forms and styles vary widely.

title: Rosary
summary: Beads guiding meditation on the life of Christ through Marian prayer.
history: Current form stabilized by 15th–16th c.; tradition links earlier promotion to St. Dominic (13th c.); numerous papal endorsements.
theology: Contemplative Christocentric prayer; sacramental when blessed; aids meditation on the mysteries of salvation.
notes: Many forms exist (Dominican, Franciscan Crown, Scriptural Rosary).

title: Brown Scapular
summary: Woolen bands worn over shoulders as a sign of Marian devotion and discipleship.
history: Associated with Carmelites (13th c.); widespread by late Middle Ages; regulations developed for enrollment and devout wearing.
theology: A sign of consecration to Mary; sacramental attached to the Carmelite family; encourages imitation of Mary’s virtues.
notes: Different scapulars exist (e.g., Red, Green, Five-Fold).

title: Medal of St. Benedict
summary: Medal bearing Benedictine symbols and exorcistic inscriptions.
history: Forms attested since the 17th c.; Jubilee medal approved 1880 for St. Benedict’s 1400th anniversary.
theology: By the Church’s blessing it becomes a sacramental of protection; inscriptions invoke the Cross of Christ.
usage: Often paired with a crucifix (Benedictine cross)
notes: Requires a specific blessing (older rite has an exorcism formula).

title: Blessed Salt
summary: Salt blessed for use in exorcisms and house blessings; recalls preservative and purifying symbolism.
history: Biblical usage (2 Kings 2:19–22); used in Roman liturgical books; sometimes added to holy water.
theology: Sacramental of protection and purification through the Church’s prayer.
notes: Use varies by pastoral norms; not for superstitious use.

title: Holy Oils
summary: Chrism, Oil of Catechumens, and Oil of the Sick; blessed by the bishop at the Chrism Mass.
history: Attested since apostolic times; systematic diocesan blessing by late antiquity.
theology: Used in sacraments; as blessed substances they also function as sacramentals when venerated and handled reverently.
notes: Stored in ambry; renewed annually in Holy Week.

title: Agnus Dei Wax Medallions
summary: Wax disks impressed with the Lamb of God; historically blessed by Popes in Eastertide.
history: Medieval origin; custom flourished in Renaissance/Baroque eras; production ceased in 20th c.
theology: Sacramental associated with Paschal mysteries and protection.
usage: Worn or kept in homes as a keepsake

title: Incense
summary: Aromatic resin burned as an offering and sign of prayer rising to God.
history: Biblical roots (Ps 141:2; Rev 8:3–4); in Christian liturgy since early centuries.
theology: Symbolizes reverence and prayer; blessing makes it a sacramental for worship.
notes: Frankincense and myrrh among common blends.

title: Palms (Palm Sunday)
summary: Blessed branches commemorating Christ’s entry into Jerusalem.
history: Attested in Jerusalem (4th c.); spread throughout the Church by the Middle Ages.
theology: Signs of victory and discipleship; kept in homes as a sacramental.
notes: Ashes often made from last year’s palms.

title: Ashes (Ash Wednesday)
summary: Blessed ashes placed on the faithful as a sign of repentance.
history: Public penance rites in the early Church; general imposition by the Middle Ages.
theology: Reminder of mortality and call to conversion; a sacramental of penance.
notes: Formulae: “Remember you are dust…” or “Repent and believe the Gospel.”

title: Candles
summary: Blessed candles (esp. at Candlemas) used in liturgy and homes; Paschal candle in Easter Vigil.
history: Widespread by late antiquity; Candlemas blessing (Feb 2) antiquity/medieval roots.
theology: Christ the Light; blessed candles carry sacramental significance.
notes: Beeswax has symbolic purity; Paschal candle renewed yearly.
